entry.et: Middle English trewthe, from Old English trēowth fidelity; akin to Old English trēowe faithful true

def.dt: :fidelity constancy
:sincerity in action, character, and utterance
:the state of being the case :fact
:the body of real things, events, and facts :actuality
:a transcendent fundamental or spiritual reality
:a judgment, proposition, or idea that is true or accepted as true truths of thermodynamics
:the body of true statements and propositions
:the property (as of a statement) of being in accord with fact or reality
:true 2
:fidelity to an original or to a standard
:god
:in accordance with fact :actually
Sojourner ca 1797–1883 Am. evangelist & reformer
:a hypnotic or anesthetic held to induce a subject under questioning to talk freely
:a mathematical or logical set containing all the elements that make a given statement of relationships true when substituted in it the equation x + 7 = 10 has as its truth set the single number 3
:a table that shows the truth-value of a compound statement for every truth-value of its component statements
:a similar table (as for a computer logic circuit) showing the value of the output for each value of each input
:the truth or falsity of a proposition or statement
:a statement that is only partially true
:a statement that mingles truth and falsehood with deliberate intent to deceive
:an unpleasant fact that jars the sensibilities
:a statement of undisputed fact
:the final sword thrust in a bullfight
:a moment of crisis on whose outcome much or everything depends
